THE NEWS. „ETTER
[.=

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 2, 1911.

VOL. XV, NO. 12.

A MILLION DOLLARS
Money on Hand Before the
Time Was Up.
HOMEWOOD SOON A REALITY
Large Gifts Received Toward
the Second Million.
Committee Receives More Than Enough
Pledges to Secure Education Board's
Gift —A Strong Effort to be Made
to Secure Remaining Sum
Within a Few Months.

The fund is half completed! The
sum of $125,000, which was still
lacking at the last publication of
THF, NEWS-LETTER, has been subscribed, and the General Education
Board's gift has been secured. On
Thursday evening, two days before
the allotted time was up, Mr.
French announced that the pledges ,
in hand totalled $812,193. The
sum in excess of $750,000 will be
applied on the second million. Several gifts, which rested on the condition of the completion of the first
million were now available. These
are:
Mr. William H. Buckler
Mrs. Thomas P. Strait
Anonymous

$20,000
to,000
15,000

Mr. Buckler cabled his donation
from England. This makes the
total of the fund to date $1,107,193.
With these three exceptions, the
contributions during the past two
weeks were all small, and it is a
splendid testimony as to the activity
of the committee that $19o,boo Wag
raised in ten days by subscriptions,
most of which were less than $500.
The alumni have responded generously and have helped to swell
the fund considerably. The classes
of '92, '99, '02, and '05, gave more ,
than $5,000 each.
There was one subscription, however, which gave a great amount of
pleasure to all interested in the University. .This was the donation by
the Yale alumni residing in Maryland. In making this gift, they referred . to the intimate relations
which had existed between Johns
Hopkins and Yale since the foundation of the former University. Dr.
Gilman himself was a Yale man.
There are now no less than fourteen
Yale alumni on the Hopkins faculty.
Similarly, there are a large number
of Hopkins men at Yale. Only last
year Dr. C. M. Andrews was appointed, head of the department of
history at Yale. The good will
which is evidenced by this subscription is very gratifying.

On Thursday the subscriptions
poured in so rapidly from all over
the State that it was impossible to
tabulate them for publication in the
evening papers. Three hundred individual contributors gave $80,000.
This flood of pledges was in response to the appeal which was sent
broadcast over the State earlier in
the week. The surplus is applied
to the second million, so that there
remains but $900,000 to be secured
before Homewood is a reality.
The General Education Board will
give twenty-five cents for every
seventy-five cents in cash received
by the committee until the pledges
are all redeemed. As a large number of the pledges call for three
annual instalments it will probably
be three years before the entire million dollars will be in the hands of
the trustees. But this is no hindrance to the progress of work at
Homewood.
ALUMNI NOTES
Dr. T. P. Maynard, and Dr. H.
McElderry Knower, were in town
over the holidays.
Dr. Knower is head of the department of anatomy at the Univesity of Cincinnati and has three
or four Hopkins men under him.
Dr. Philip Ogden, also of the
University of Cincinnati, came back
to town for ,the holidays.
Prof. E. F'. Buchner is the editor
of the department of biography and
philosophy in the new "Cyclopedia
of Education," which has just appeared from the press of The Macmillan Company.
Dr. John C. Hilt, A.B.,'03; Ph.D.,
'o6, instructor in . history at Smith
College, was at the University during the holidays.
Dr. T. A. Lewis, Ph.D., 'io, of
Richmond, Va., was here last week.
Dr. L. C. Barrett, Ph.D.,'03, preceptor at Princeton University, was
in Baltimore during Christmas
week.
Thomas Bevan, '09, is in Mexico.
Leo Gutman,'09, is working with
the Mann Piano Company.
Harry Deale, '09, went North for
a short time during the holidays.
H. K. Flardcastle, '09, is in town.
Franklin Orion, '09, is working
in a law office in the Equitable
Building. He will take his bar examination this year.
W. Z. White, '09, is with the
Chalmers-Detroit Company, in the
Middle West.
Ben. Weems, '09, is studying
medicine in Germany. He will return at Easter time.
R. N. Larrimore, '09, is in his
father's office, in Baltimore.

ATHLETIC PROSPECTS BRIGHT
Hopkins Should Exceed all Past Performances This Year—Many Candidates for Teams The Football
Blowout.

The year 1911 should should be
a banner one for Hopkins athletics,
for many reasons. In the first
place the number of undergraduates
is about twenty-five per cent.
greater than last year, and consequently there should be more candidates for the teams. Secondly,
all the athletic squads will start
with an unusually large number of
veterans as a nucleus. Thirdly, the
managers of the various athletic
teams have been able to arrange
better schedules for the 1911 .seasons than ever heretofore. And,last,
but not least, there will be an officially recognized Hopkins baseball
team for the first time in many
years.
Candidates for the Black and
Blue lacrosse team have been practicing regularly under Coach Meyer
for the past month. The "green"
members of the squad are rapidly
learning the rudimentary principles
of the game. Although their stickwork is not yet perfect, Coach
Meyer will begin in a few days
to drill the candidates in the Hopkins system of play. Captain Hulburt is especially anxious to win
back the championship of the southern division of the intercollegiate
lacrosse league, which Hopkins lost
last spring for the first time in five
years. Swarthmore, the present
holder of the championship, will
probably be as last year, Hopkins'
most formidable opponent. The
Quakers lost but two members of
their crack twelve, and are, therefore, likely to figure prominently in
the contest for the coveted banner.
Hopkins will play all the strongest
teams in the northern division, so
that, if it wins all its games this
season, it will have a clear title to
the national championship.
On the cindertrack the wearers
of the Black and Blue'hope to give
a good account of themselves. The
full strength of the squad is as
yet unknown, but in Captain Fulton, Horrax, Hunter, and Morton,
Hopkins has suKe point winners.
The track candidates were given a
rest during the holidays, but beginning this week they will get down
to daily work under Coach Kocker.
The indoor season will begin in
February, and the athletes will have
plenty of opportunity to win glory
for Hopkins and for themselves.
The dual meet between the sophomores and freshmen will come pff
near the end of January, and this
will serve as incentive for the sophs •
and freshies to join the track squad.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS
The sophomores have elected Billy
Ray captain of their class trackteam, and the freshmen will probably elect their leader in a few
days.
Manager Sattler is arranging a
fine schedule for the baseball team.
It includes games with University
of Pennsylvania, Columbia and some
other strong and well known nines.
If baseball is a failure, it will not
be on account of lack of good
games. But it might be said right
here that baseball is not going to
be a failure. Captain Pieper has
heard from a large number of prospective candidates, many of whom
have made reputations for themselves on their prep school and college nines. From present indications, baseball bids fair to become
more popular than lacrosse.
The gymnasium is to be equipped with basketball goals, and the
students who are fond of the game
will soon have an opportunity of
playing. Prof. Kistler has already
arranged for a league among the
members of the freshman gymnasium class. There will be six teams
and the captains have already been.
elected. They will pick their teams
shortly. The other classes will probably organize quintets, and it is
quite possible that an interclass
league may be formed. If the game
arouses enough interest, Hopkins
will probably have a regular varsity
team next year.
But lest we forget. The football
players have not been given their
customary blow-out. They deserve
one as they made a splendid record
on the gridiron. The players appreciate their "H's" and "H. A. A's."
much more when they are presented
before a gathering of their fellow
students. Everybody has a good
time and we ought to give the team
their blow-out even if it is a little
late. Since the Athletic Association
does not see its way clear to financing such an entertainment, the student body should do it by individual
subscription. Let's make arrangements for it at once. Any suggestions will be welcomed by THE

In the new Arbitration Society
there has come into the University
a factor that should be of value in
forming the views of the students
on a topic of world-wide importance. If a sufficient membership
can be secured, the organization will
doubtless explain its purposes by
carrying them out, but while it remains in an experimental stage it
needs the assistance and support of
more members. The news columns
of THE NEWS-LETTER have, from
time to time, contained statements
of the purpose and activities of the
society, though in a few weeks
since its organization it has been
able to accomplish less than may
be, expected when it has gathered
more headway: Just at present anyone who is interested in any degree
in the cause of peace, or who cares
to inform himself on the subject,
can aid the society materially by
enrolling as a member. Talk it
over with any one of the officers.

Oratorical Contest to be Held.

Musical Clubs Give Concert.

The Intercollegiate Peace Association will .hold an intercollegiate
oratorical contestfor the State of
Maryland at Hopkins during the
coming March. Each college is entitled to one representative. The
local arrangements are in charge of
the Arbitration Society which is arranging a preliminary contest to
pick a Hopkins representative. This
contest will be held about the end
of January, and the representative
will be picked by Dr. J. C. French.
Candidates are requested to hand
their names to the chairman of the
committee, Mr. R. E. Miller.
The rules governing the contest
are as follows:
(I.) Orations shall deal with
some phase of the general subject
of international arbitration, and
peace.
(2.) Orations shall be limited to
sixteen minutes in delivery.
(3.) First prize, $75; second
prize, $50.
(4.) Orations must be original.

The Glee and Musical Clubs took
the second trip of the season last
week. The • concert was given at
Chestertown, Md. The Clubs left
on the morning boat from Light
Street Wharf and arrived in time
for supper. On the way down the
other passengers on the boat were
entertained by songs and instrumental music. The crowd at the
concert was not as large as could
have been desired, owing to several
rival attractions, but the audience
was appreciative. The quartette
was encored several times and
"Stonie's'' medley made a hit. The
chorus sang two University songs
with great effect. After the concert
most of the boys attended a dance
and didn't "get home until morning." It was a sleepy crowd that
left at 8 A. M. for Baltimore.
Those taking the trip were: Ray,
Geisel, Hulburt, Wagner, Jacobs,
Merrick, Lauchheimer, Jenkins,
Peirce, King, Hering, Uhlig, Dornblayer, Fulton, Schmidt, Weyforth,
Warner, Stollenwerck, Stockett,
Gillet, Martin, Leland, White,
Lloyd, Ruth, Tappan, Brenninger,
Weber, and Coblentz.

Fun in French.

In one of the French classes, the
other day, a gentleman who prefers that his name should not be
mentioned, coming to the phrase
'"Depuis huitans" in an ode addressed to an old coat, translated
it "the coat which I have had since
I was eight years old." The instructor said that the correct translation was "the coat which I have
had for eight years," which would
make it old enough. He added
that the gentleman in question
translated the sentence as though
he were eight years old.

THE NEWS. „ETTER
[.=

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 2, 1911.

VOL. XV, NO. 12.

A MILLION DOLLARS
Money on Hand Before the
Time Was Up.
HOMEWOOD SOON A REALITY
Large Gifts Received Toward
the Second Million.
Committee Receives More Than Enough
Pledges to Secure Education Board's
Gift —A Strong Effort to be Made
to Secure Remaining Sum
Within a Few Months.

The fund is half completed! The
sum of $125,000, which was still
lacking at the last publication of
THF, NEWS-LETTER, has been subscribed, and the General Education
Board's gift has been secured. On
Thursday evening, two days before
the allotted time was up, Mr.
French announced that the pledges ,
in hand totalled $812,193. The
sum in excess of $750,000 will be
applied on the second million. Several gifts, which rested on the condition of the completion of the first
million were now available. These
are:
Mr. William H. Buckler
Mrs. Thomas P. Strait
Anonymous

$20,000
to,000
15,000

Mr. Buckler cabled his donation
from England. This makes the
total of the fund to date $1,107,193.
With these three exceptions, the
contributions during the past two
weeks were all small, and it is a
splendid testimony as to the activity
of the committee that $19o,boo Wag
raised in ten days by subscriptions,
most of which were less than $500.
The alumni have responded generously and have helped to swell
the fund considerably. The classes
of '92, '99, '02, and '05, gave more ,
than $5,000 each.
There was one subscription, however, which gave a great amount of
pleasure to all interested in the University. .This was the donation by
the Yale alumni residing in Maryland. In making this gift, they referred . to the intimate relations
which had existed between Johns
Hopkins and Yale since the foundation of the former University. Dr.
Gilman himself was a Yale man.
There are now no less than fourteen
Yale alumni on the Hopkins faculty.
Similarly, there are a large number
of Hopkins men at Yale. Only last
year Dr. C. M. Andrews was appointed, head of the department of
history at Yale. The good will
which is evidenced by this subscription is very gratifying.

On Thursday the subscriptions
poured in so rapidly from all over
the State that it was impossible to
tabulate them for publication in the
evening papers. Three hundred individual contributors gave $80,000.
This flood of pledges was in response to the appeal which was sent
broadcast over the State earlier in
the week. The surplus is applied
to the second million, so that there
remains but $900,000 to be secured
before Homewood is a reality.
The General Education Board will
give twenty-five cents for every
seventy-five cents in cash received
by the committee until the pledges
are all redeemed. As a large number of the pledges call for three
annual instalments it will probably
be three years before the entire million dollars will be in the hands of
the trustees. But this is no hindrance to the progress of work at
Homewood.
ALUMNI NOTES
Dr. T. P. Maynard, and Dr. H.
McElderry Knower, were in town
over the holidays.
Dr. Knower is head of the department of anatomy at the Univesity of Cincinnati and has three
or four Hopkins men under him.
Dr. Philip Ogden, also of the
University of Cincinnati, came back
to town for ,the holidays.
Prof. E. F'. Buchner is the editor
of the department of biography and
philosophy in the new "Cyclopedia
of Education," which has just appeared from the press of The Macmillan Company.
Dr. John C. Hilt, A.B.,'03; Ph.D.,
'o6, instructor in . history at Smith
College, was at the University during the holidays.
Dr. T. A. Lewis, Ph.D., 'io, of
Richmond, Va., was here last week.
Dr. L. C. Barrett, Ph.D.,'03, preceptor at Princeton University, was
in Baltimore during Christmas
week.
Thomas Bevan, '09, is in Mexico.
Leo Gutman,'09, is working with
the Mann Piano Company.
Harry Deale, '09, went North for
a short time during the holidays.
H. K. Flardcastle, '09, is in town.
Franklin Orion, '09, is working
in a law office in the Equitable
Building. He will take his bar examination this year.
W. Z. White, '09, is with the
Chalmers-Detroit Company, in the
Middle West.
Ben. Weems, '09, is studying
medicine in Germany. He will return at Easter time.
R. N. Larrimore, '09, is in his
father's office, in Baltimore.

ATHLETIC PROSPECTS BRIGHT
Hopkins Should Exceed all Past Performances This Year—Many Candidates for Teams The Football
Blowout.

The year 1911 should should be
a banner one for Hopkins athletics,
for many reasons. In the first
place the number of undergraduates
is about twenty-five per cent.
greater than last year, and consequently there should be more candidates for the teams. Secondly,
all the athletic squads will start
with an unusually large number of
veterans as a nucleus. Thirdly, the
managers of the various athletic
teams have been able to arrange
better schedules for the 1911 .seasons than ever heretofore. And,last,
but not least, there will be an officially recognized Hopkins baseball
team for the first time in many
years.
Candidates for the Black and
Blue lacrosse team have been practicing regularly under Coach Meyer
for the past month. The "green"
members of the squad are rapidly
learning the rudimentary principles
of the game. Although their stickwork is not yet perfect, Coach
Meyer will begin in a few days
to drill the candidates in the Hopkins system of play. Captain Hulburt is especially anxious to win
back the championship of the southern division of the intercollegiate
lacrosse league, which Hopkins lost
last spring for the first time in five
years. Swarthmore, the present
holder of the championship, will
probably be as last year, Hopkins'
most formidable opponent. The
Quakers lost but two members of
their crack twelve, and are, therefore, likely to figure prominently in
the contest for the coveted banner.
Hopkins will play all the strongest
teams in the northern division, so
that, if it wins all its games this
season, it will have a clear title to
the national championship.
On the cindertrack the wearers
of the Black and Blue'hope to give
a good account of themselves. The
full strength of the squad is as
yet unknown, but in Captain Fulton, Horrax, Hunter, and Morton,
Hopkins has suKe point winners.
The track candidates were given a
rest during the holidays, but beginning this week they will get down
to daily work under Coach Kocker.
The indoor season will begin in
February, and the athletes will have
plenty of opportunity to win glory
for Hopkins and for themselves.
The dual meet between the sophomores and freshmen will come pff
near the end of January, and this
will serve as incentive for the sophs •
and freshies to join the track squad.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS
The sophomores have elected Billy
Ray captain of their class trackteam, and the freshmen will probably elect their leader in a few
days.
Manager Sattler is arranging a
fine schedule for the baseball team.
It includes games with University
of Pennsylvania, Columbia and some
other strong and well known nines.
If baseball is a failure, it will not
be on account of lack of good
games. But it might be said right
here that baseball is not going to
be a failure. Captain Pieper has
heard from a large number of prospective candidates, many of whom
have made reputations for themselves on their prep school and college nines. From present indications, baseball bids fair to become
more popular than lacrosse.
The gymnasium is to be equipped with basketball goals, and the
students who are fond of the game
will soon have an opportunity of
playing. Prof. Kistler has already
arranged for a league among the
members of the freshman gymnasium class. There will be six teams
and the captains have already been.
elected. They will pick their teams
shortly. The other classes will probably organize quintets, and it is
quite possible that an interclass
league may be formed. If the game
arouses enough interest, Hopkins
will probably have a regular varsity
team next year.
But lest we forget. The football
players have not been given their
customary blow-out. They deserve
one as they made a splendid record
on the gridiron. The players appreciate their "H's" and "H. A. A's."
much more when they are presented
before a gathering of their fellow
students. Everybody has a good
time and we ought to give the team
their blow-out even if it is a little
late. Since the Athletic Association
does not see its way clear to financing such an entertainment, the student body should do it by individual
subscription. Let's make arrangements for it at once. Any suggestions will be welcomed by THE

In the new Arbitration Society
there has come into the University
a factor that should be of value in
forming the views of the students
on a topic of world-wide importance. If a sufficient membership
can be secured, the organization will
doubtless explain its purposes by
carrying them out, but while it remains in an experimental stage it
needs the assistance and support of
more members. The news columns
of THE NEWS-LETTER have, from
time to time, contained statements
of the purpose and activities of the
society, though in a few weeks
since its organization it has been
able to accomplish less than may
be, expected when it has gathered
more headway: Just at present anyone who is interested in any degree
in the cause of peace, or who cares
to inform himself on the subject,
can aid the society materially by
enrolling as a member. Talk it
over with any one of the officers.

Oratorical Contest to be Held.

Musical Clubs Give Concert.

The Intercollegiate Peace Association will .hold an intercollegiate
oratorical contestfor the State of
Maryland at Hopkins during the
coming March. Each college is entitled to one representative. The
local arrangements are in charge of
the Arbitration Society which is arranging a preliminary contest to
pick a Hopkins representative. This
contest will be held about the end
of January, and the representative
will be picked by Dr. J. C. French.
Candidates are requested to hand
their names to the chairman of the
committee, Mr. R. E. Miller.
The rules governing the contest
are as follows:
(I.) Orations shall deal with
some phase of the general subject
of international arbitration, and
peace.
(2.) Orations shall be limited to
sixteen minutes in delivery.
(3.) First prize, $75; second
prize, $50.
(4.) Orations must be original.

The Glee and Musical Clubs took
the second trip of the season last
week. The • concert was given at
Chestertown, Md. The Clubs left
on the morning boat from Light
Street Wharf and arrived in time
for supper. On the way down the
other passengers on the boat were
entertained by songs and instrumental music. The crowd at the
concert was not as large as could
have been desired, owing to several
rival attractions, but the audience
was appreciative. The quartette
was encored several times and
"Stonie's'' medley made a hit. The
chorus sang two University songs
with great effect. After the concert
most of the boys attended a dance
and didn't "get home until morning." It was a sleepy crowd that
left at 8 A. M. for Baltimore.
Those taking the trip were: Ray,
Geisel, Hulburt, Wagner, Jacobs,
Merrick, Lauchheimer, Jenkins,
Peirce, King, Hering, Uhlig, Dornblayer, Fulton, Schmidt, Weyforth,
Warner, Stollenwerck, Stockett,
Gillet, Martin, Leland, White,
Lloyd, Ruth, Tappan, Brenninger,
Weber, and Coblentz.

Fun in French.

In one of the French classes, the
other day, a gentleman who prefers that his name should not be
mentioned, coming to the phrase
'"Depuis huitans" in an ode addressed to an old coat, translated
it "the coat which I have had since
I was eight years old." The instructor said that the correct translation was "the coat which I have
had for eight years," which would
make it old enough. He added
that the gentleman in question
translated the sentence as though
he were eight years old.
